title: MOTHERS URGE BAN ON SURROGACY AS FORM OF 'SLAVERY'
text:
A group of mothers who agreed to bear children under surrogacy contracts said today that they wanted their babies returned and called on Congress and state governments to outlaw the practice, which they called ''an institutionalized form of slavery.''

The women, including Mary Beth Whitehead, a New Jersey resident who earlier this year lost custody of her daughter in the Baby M case, said they were joining a coalition to ban surrogacy, one of the most popular of the reproductive technologies developed in the last decade to enable infertile couples to have children. 'Just Not Right'

''This shouldn't be allowed to happen,'' said Mrs. Whitehead, who was paid $10,000 in 1986 by a New Jersey couple, William and Elizabeth Stern, to bear Mr. Stern's child. ''Don't let it happen to anybody else. It's just not right.''

The coalition opposing surrogacy was organized by Jeremy Rifkin, president of the Foundation on Economic Trends, a small public policy group in Washington that has influenced the national debate on developments in biotechnology. Mr. Rifkin said today that more surrogate mothers are bringing legal action to gain custody of their children.
authors: Special To The New York Times
